report_title: Industry Report on Boxing Gyms and Clubs
executive_summary: Over the past five years, boxing gyms and clubs struggled against economic disruption and external competition, though favorable demographic trends like an aging population and increased disposable incomes have offered a cushion of support. Fitness services are discretionary, so changes to the external environment affect how much consumers are willing to splurge on boxing gym memberships.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Revenue collapsed at a CAGR of 7.7% over the past few years
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Revenue collapsed at a CAGR of 7.7% over the past few years and will reach $1.0 billion in 2024, including a 1.5% loss that year.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Profit rebounded quickly, supported by growing participation post-pandemic
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Profit rebounded quickly, supported by growing participation post-pandemic. Recently, boxing clubs and gyms have seen a mixed bag of developments.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Virtual Classes and Tech Integration Shapes Offerings
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Many boxing gyms have expanded their offerings to retain members and attract new ones. Virtual training and online consultations have become popular in the last few years.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: High Level of External Competition Limited Growth
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Boxing gyms and clubs face stiff competition from alternative fitness and leisure activities. The rising availability of free and home workouts has made consumers hesitant to invest in expensive boxing gear and memberships.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Emphasis on Health Will Likely Accelerate Niche
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: A resurgence in the popularity of High-Intensity Interval Training (HIIT) and functional training styles, which align with boxing workouts, will attract fitness enthusiasts seeking efficient, full-body workouts.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: The Continuous Presence of External Competitors is Poised to Dampen Large-Scale Revenue Growth
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Although boxing remains a popular activity among a variety of customers, the prevalence of online fitness classes and alternative work-outs will limit the future rate of growth.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Hybrid Classes Appeal to Gen Z
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: The continued popularity of online fitness classes and alternative activities will hinder large-scale revenue growth for boxing gyms. As competition intensifies, a hybrid model, offering both in-person and online sessions, will be critical to attract convenience-focused consumers.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: VR and XR Technology Will Revolutionize the Boxing Experience
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: VR boxing, once underwhelming, is improving rapidly. Enhanced VR shadow boxing allows beginners to learn the basics comfortably, reducing intimidation associated with joining boxing clubs.

industry_definition: Boxing gyms and clubs include facilities that provide instruction on the sport of boxing, the practice of fist fighting with padded gloves within a roped square ring. This industry does not include boxing event promoters or organizers.

negative_impact_factors: Barriers To Entry Level low - steady

key_trends: High-quality service in boxing classes can drive internal competition.
The accelerated adoption of home fitness is strengthening external competition.
Boxing's popularity will surge thanks to health-conscious trends
Boxing gyms and clubs have no major companies
Steady growth in per capita disposable income strengthens consumer propensity
A consistent regulatory landscape contributes to limited operational costs
Falling memberships don't reduce the operating costs for boxing gyms, which remain constant
Wage costs are the largest expenditure for boxing gyms
Large population presence creates incentive for new establishments
Colder weather is a beneficial factor
High consumer demand establishes a large revenue stream among membership fees

market_segmentation.segment_description: This market segment generates revenue among customers in Generation Z, which refers to people born between 1997 and 2012.
This market segment generates revenue among millennials, which refers to people born between 1981 and 1996.
This market segment generates revenue among Generation X customers, which refers to people born between 1965 and 1980.
This market segment generates revenue among baby boomers, which refers to people born between 1946 and 1964.

products_and_services.product_description: This product segment generates revenue via membership fees when selling membership plans to consumers.
This product segment generates revenue via personal training and private boxing sessions.
This product segment generates revenue via the sale of merchandise and apparel, like boxing gloves, hand wraps, protective headgear and training pads.
This product segment generates revenue via the sales of food, drinks and admissions for sporting events.

tier_1_suppliers: Athletic & Sporting Goods Manufacturing in the US
Gym & Exercise Equipment Manufacturing in the US
tier_2_suppliers: Steam & Air-Conditioning Supply in the US
tier_2_buyers: Racing & Individual Sports in the US

demand_determinants.determinant_description: As per capita disposable income rises, more individuals will have the available funds to join boxing gyms and attend boxing classes. In addition, higher per capita disposable income may benefit the industry by stimulating consumer demand for its ancillary products (e.g. merchandise and supplements). Growth in per capita disposable income represents a potential opportunity for boxing gyms and clubs.

When more people become aware of the importance of maintaining physical fitness, they are more likely to belong to a boxing gym or club. Growth in sports participation stimulates revenue growth for boxing gyms and clubs, as it entails higher interest among consumers to be active in their physical health.

Consumers aged 20 to 64 represent the largest market for boxing gyms and clubs. As the number of consumers in this age range expands, the demand for boxing services increases proportionally, broadening the customer base.

The national unemployment rate gauges the current number of Americans over the age of 16 that are currently unemployed and are actively looking for work. Lower rates of unemployment bolsters consumers' fiscal capability to pursue a boxing club membership, benefiting operator demand. A rise in the national unemployment poses a potential threat to operators.

business_locations.location_description: With a majority of the US population located in the Southeast, this region attracts many establishments thanks to a dense customer base.
The Western region has a favorable weather climate that enables consumers to walk and travel short distances to their local boxing club or gym.

The Mid-Atlantic region's storied boxing history, with cities like Philadelphia producing numerous champions, fuels a strong local interest in the sport and supports a vibrant network of boxing clubs and gyms.
The Southwest's close proximity to Mexico, where boxing is a major sport, significantly influences the region, fostering a strong boxing culture and the establishment of many clubs and gyms.

regulations_points.regulation_description: The Federal Trade Commission (FTC) rules and regulations, along with other consumer protection agency guidelines, govern franchising, advertising,

Boxing clubs and gym must adhere to numerous regulations, like the Truth-in-Lending Act and Regulation Z. State and provincial laws on debt collection also impact how boxing gyms manage memberships and financing. Interpretation of these laws varies among federal, state and provincial enforcement agencies, adding uncertainty. Courts can interpret these regulations differently, contributing to industry volatility.

Under so-called cooling off statutes in most states and provinces, new members of fitness centers have the right to cancel their memberships for a period of three to fifteen days after the date the contract was entered into and are entitled to refunds of any payment made. The amount of time new members have to cancel their membership contract depends on the applicable state or provincial law.

Advertising of nutritional products is subject to regulation by the Food and Drug Administration (FDA) and the Federal Trade Commission (FTC). Both agencies' regulations create a framework that influences how nutritional products are marketed, impacting industry practices and consumer trust. The FDA oversees the formulation, manufacturing, safety and labeling of vitamins and other supplements. The FTC regulates marketing and advertising claims to prevent deceptive practices.

barriers_points.barrier_description: New entrants in the boxing gym industry encounter limited regulatory barriers. They adhere mainly to regulations on membership contracts, customer safety, and local licensing standards.
Boxing gyms face limited start-up costs. Initial investments primarily encompass equipment procurement, employee hiring and obtaining necessary operating licenses.
Differentiation within the industry is minimal. In most boxing gyms, revenue is concentrated on selling boxing classes, training sessions, and facility access.
Although some capital is necessary for equipment purchases, labor intensity is significantly higher. Continuous employee presence is necessary.
Significant initial capital is needed for high-quality boxing equipment, facility renovations and hiring qualified trainers.

basis_points.basis_title: High-quality service in boxing classes can drive internal competition
basis_points.basis_description: Thanks to positive consumer sentiment, those who excel can attract more customers, leading to higher profitability and business growth.
As consumers seek convenient access to fitness and training classes, they're taking classes online and buying fitness equipment for their homes.

concentration_points.concentration_title: High saturation of nonemploying establishments dampens concentration
concentration_points.concentration_description: Since boxing gyms and clubs require little space or physical employees, it establishes a unique demand niche for small facilities with one main employer.
Boxing gyms and clubs are highly dependent on localized demand native to the region they operate in, with areas that have larger population concentration a popular target for growth.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: STEADY DEMAND FOR ADMINISTRATIVE TASKS MAINTAINS HIGH GENERAL ADMINISTRATION COSTS
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Some of the other costs incurred by operators include general administration, IT and insurance costs. These expenses are necessary to ensure the efficient functioning of a facility and that there is adequate coverage, particularly for injury liability. These costs contracted over the last few years as attendance at boxing gyms fell.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: CONSISTENT DEMAND FOR EMPLOYEE PRESENCE BOLSTERS WAGE COSTS
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Boxing gyms and clubs require a consistent employee presence so that they can service customers, train clients and process administrative tasks. With inflationary pressures growing and state-wide minimum wages on the incline, operators continue to contend with mounting wage costs across the market.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: Virtual classes created additional roles for instructors and tech support, inflating wage costs.
FALLING MEMBERSHIPS AT BOXING GYMS DAMPENS PROFITS
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Many consumers prefer to pursue their physical activities at home or in outdoor settings. When consumer preferences turn away from boxing, revenue falls but costs stay the same. With the growing adoption of online classes among traditional fitness centers, this competition attracted many core customers away from boxing clubs and gyms, harming profit.

capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_description: Although some capital is necessary for equipment purchases, labor intensity is significantly higher. Continuous employee presence is necessary, with raw labor necessary to perform administrative tasks and conduct training for clients.

Significant initial capital is needed for high-quality boxing equipment, facility renovations and hiring qualified trainers, making it difficult for new entrants without substantial financial resources to compete.

volatility_points.volatility_title: ACCELERATED ADOPTION OF ONLINE WORKOUT PLATFORMS HEIGHTENS VOLATILITY
volatility_points.volatility_description: As more consumers continue to adapt online training and fitness classes, traditional boxing gyms and clubs face significant uncertainty across their core revenue streams. Boxing clubs and gyms continue to face high volatility due to more customers shifting their propensity toward less expensive leisure activities.

technological_change_points.technological_change_title: ACCELERATED ADOPTION OF UPGRADED EQUIPMENT BOOSTS
technological_change_points.technological_change_description: Although boxing clubs and gyms have no unique innovative aspects within their product stream, they have been able to incorporate advances in equipment to improve their customer service. Upgrades in cardiovascular equipment that enable entertainment and improved health metric readings ensures boxing gyms and clubs remain ahead of the curve when it comes to updating machinery.

FAQs.question: How well does your company market to consumers with limited leisure time?
FAQs.answer: Some operators market to time-strapped consumers with workout classes that take half an hour or less.

FAQs.question: Is your revenue sensitive to changes in discretionary spending?
FAQs.answer: Since boxing gyms are considered discretionary, demand typically trends in line with disposable income. Demand for the industry's ancillary services, like personal training, is particularly sensitive to discretionary spending levels.

FAQs.question: If your company benefits from population density, are you located in high traffic areas to increase your exposure?
FAQs.answer: While many consumers will look for the gym with the lowest price or best amenities, most are prone to joining the gym that is closest to their work or house. Therefore, operators located in densely populated areas benefit from high demand.

FAQs.question: Have you considered acquisitions to achieve higher operating efficiencies?
FAQs.answer: While mergers and acquisitions are not rampant in this industry, they occasionally occur. For example, UFC Gym acquired LA Boxing in 2013, which expanded its market share industry significantly.

FAQs.question: Has your company explored lowering wage costs through part-time labor and automation via point-of-sale systems?
FAQs.answer: Since high-skilled trainers are a major selling point for this industry, operators struggle to replace employees with automated technological systems.

FAQs.question: Has your company updated facilities in order to enhance the consumer experience?
FAQs.answer: Operators that have state-of-the-art equipment, like TV screens on exercise machines, are likely to experience higher levels of demand than operators that do not.

FAQs.question: Are you subject to specific franchising laws that may hinder growth?
FAQs.answer: All of the largest industry players operate under a franchise model, and must adhere to specific requests from the parent company.

FAQs.question: Do you offer membership agreements, tickets or passes that may be subject to state or federal regulation?
FAQs.answer: Membership fees are the largest income source for this industry. Operators must comply with the cooling-off law for membership agreements, that allow consumers to void a contract within a specified period of time after signing.

FAQs.question: Do you have a high retention rate among consumers under contract?
FAQs.answer: Operators rely on consumer to renew their contracts, since membership fees represent the largest income source for this industry. Operators work hard to retain clients through offering high-skilled trainers and up-to-date equipment. Title Boxing Club has a net promoter score of 87%.

FAQs.question: Does your company have to purchase new equipment on an annual basis?
FAQs.answer: While operators generally do not need to purchase new equipment on an annual basis, those that do gain the reputation of having up-to-date equipment. Consumers are generally attracted to facilities with state-of-the-art equipment.

FAQs.question: How important is location for this industry? Do you set up your facilities in high-traffic areas?
FAQs.answer: A high profile location offering easy access and parking can provide a competitive advantage for operators in this industry.

FAQs.question: How do you promote your products? What marketing strategies do you have in place to attract customers?
FAQs.answer: Boxing gyms must be able to promote their services effectively to attract new members. Many operators offer a trial period for new members.

FAQs.question: What is the skill level of your trainers? What are the difficulties in maintaining a skilled workforce?
FAQs.answer: Skilled staff members that can demonstrate the use of various types of equipment and assist members are important to attract new and repeat customers.

FAQs.question: What is the biggest source of external competition for your company? How do you contend with competitive pressure from other gyms?
FAQs.answer: Competition from athletic substitutes, such as general fitness centers, yoga studios and swimming pools, represent a significant source of external competition for the industry. Recently, online-based workout videos have presented an additional source of external competition.

FAQs.question: Do you notice an increase in revenue as sports participation increases? How does your company take advantage of higher sports participation?
FAQs.answer: When more people become aware of the importance of maintaining physical fitness, they are more likely to belong to a boxing gym or club. Widespread media coverage of boxing championships has had a positive effect on the industry.

FAQs.question: Do you monitor per capita disposable income? Are your offerings considered discretionary or essential for consumers?
FAQs.answer: As per capita disposable income rises, more individuals will have the available funds to join boxing gyms and attend boxing classes.
